Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Linking climate-driven changes in erosion to tectonic processes along the southern Alaska Margin
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most challenging questions in active mountain building is how climate might drive tectonic processes, in the form of mass redistribution. In other words, do climate-driven changes in erosion lead to increased exposure of mountainous belts, and perhaps influence tectonic processes, like uplift and faulting, as predicted by numerical models? The study of this question, by means of observational and analytical data is challenging because most areas where active mountain building is occurring are covered by remnant glaciers and glaciated landscapes from the end of the Neogene period (23 ? 2.5 million years ago). The St. Elias mountain belt, in southeast Alaska, is a prime location to address this question due to its extensive glaciation. The recent erosional record of this active mountain range is stored in the Gulf of Alaska and was recovered during Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) Expedition 341. Integrated analysis of deep-sea core material obtained from drilling at the continental shelf, slope, and the deep-sea Surveyor Fan will provide means to quantify the effect of global and local climate changes on the erosional and structural evolution of a mountain range. The youthfulness of the St. Elias belt, along with high rates of tectonic and erosional processes, and its close proximity of the Gulf of Alaska provide an ideal natural setting to study climate-tectonic interactions.

Long-standing debates exist in the Earth sciences on whether Neogene climate change affects rates of surface processes, such as erosion, and consequently influences tectonic processes, such as faulting, through redistribution of mass. The proposed study will test the hypothesis that an increase in glacial erosion has led to focused exhumation in the core of the St. Elias orogeny as proposed by numerical and analytical data. Two possible target regions have been suggested where a tectonic-climate feedback may have developed: in the fold-thrust belt and at the indenting Yakutat plate corner. The wealth of existing onshore geo- and thermochronological data provide a comprehensive picture of the current spatial pattern of exhumation rates, but the quantification of changes in rates and patterns through time has been challenging. The research team?s approach is to investigate the offshore sedimentary record of the St. Elias orogeny deposited in the Gulf of Alaska. This orogeny developed during a period of significant global climate change, including the intensification of Northern Hemisphere glaciation (iNHG) at the Plio-Pleistogene transition (PPT), ~2.6 Ma, and the mid-Pleistocene transition (MPT) from 1.2 to 0.7 Ma, but also a change of local climate resulting in alpine glaciers, perhaps as early as the Late Miocene/Pliocene (6.5 Ma). The high-resolution magnetostratigraphic and biostratigraphic age control from the IODP Expedition 341 cores allow close linking of changes in sedimentary lithofacies and textures, provenanace, exhumation, and sediment routing and distribution, to test the record of climate-tectonic interactions along the southern Alaska margin. The integration of Gulf of Alaska seismic reflection data with the age and provenance control from the 341 cores allow examination of sediment mass flux in the regional offshore depositional system, the Surveyor Fan, from a 3-D perspective through time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Humans often view mountain ranges as everlasting features on the landscape of the Earth. However, these are not static features, and people living in mountainous regions experience the forces that build them when large earthquakes occur, such as events in the past year in New Zealand, Italy, and Iran.  These earthquakes occur along faults, where the rock is weakest. Geologists have speculated for decades whether the location of these faults in mountains can be influenced by the loss of rock from erosion. A good analogy is to imagine a person doing a push-up with a heavy weight on their lower back. They will struggle and push themselves up. If you remove that weight, they will perform the push-up in a much different way. This holds for mountains; if you remove weight from them, the earthquake faults within them will change their location and how they build up the mountains over time. This loss of weight, or mass, results from the erosion of rock. We are unsure if erosion can continue in a relatively small area (for example, the size of the state of Vermot) over a time span long enough to impact how faulting and earthquakes occur in mountains. In many mountains, erosion is done by glaciers, which are known to carve out large amounts of rock like Yosemite Valley in California.

 

 With this project, we wanted to determine if the large glaciers in Alaska play a role in the formation of the largest coastal mountain range on Earth, the St. Elias range in southern Alaska. Other geologists have shown that these mountains are still being built up by large earthquakes. Glaciers erode the rock of the St. Elais range, and along with rivers transport this material into the ocean where it ultimately becomes buried on the seafloor, forming layers of rock (or sediment) over time. We sampled these rocks and sediments using a deep-sea drilling ship in 2013.  We used CT-scans, just like done on people, to analyze the samples and create images of the layers within the sediment cores. We found that glacial ice flow extends from the mountains into the ocean during the ice ages of the past one million years. We also found that glaciers have been eroding the mountains in the very same place, roughly a 500 sq. mile region, over this same time period, which turns out to be where there are modern earthquake faults. Over the past decace, other geologists have discovered that the location of these faults in the mountains can shift from one part of the range to another (~10-20 miles) over <100,000 years, a short time geologically. Our results suggest that the location of these faults right now is controlled by the continual erosion of rock from this relatively small area. Rock is moving up from deeper in the Earth to replace the rock eroded by the glaciers. This is the best example on the planet of how the erosion of mountains can directly influence how mountains once again built up over geologic time.

 

An important part of this project was training undergraduate and graduate students in the use of technologically advanced tools and equipment to analyze the sediment cores and samples. These tools are used in many geologic occupations such as in the oil and gas industry and by geologists studying groundwater. We also have been able to share the results and data with other scientists through presentations at scientific meetings and with submission of our work to an open-access journal (Geosphere) so that the public have access to the work and data.
